title: ENG09_pt 1: 5.1 Who's Who in Verona: Romeo and Juliet | SVHS

mainContent.text:
5.1 Who's Who in Verona: Romeo and Juliet

        Completion requirements
        



If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 5, you can open it in Google Docs. Use the
    study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too. Review the assignment for this unit. Think about it as you are reading the book. Collect ideas and make notes. 

The Play's the Thing
Shakespeare's Tragedy of Romeo & Juliet is an early play by the great Elizabethan playwright, adapted from an Italian story of romance.  In the play, Shakespeare confronts the dualities of love and death, those two extremes that propel
    the young lovers into each others' arms.  
The play begins with a sonnet which, *SPOILER*, gives a synopsis of the play by the Chorus as a kind of preview that you might see in a movie theater.  His famous line about the "star-crossed lovers" juxtaposes the fate versus free
    will themes of love and death.  It's a classic teenage romance in which we are ironically attracted to those who may both love and hurt us most.
The play's setting, the city-state of Verona, Italy, tells of two rival families, the Montagues (Romeo's family) and Capulets (Juliet's family).  Each family mirrors the other according to character parallels or foils (reflections
    of each other):

    
    
        
            Who's Who in Verona
            Montagues
            Capulets
            Neutral
        
    
    
        
            Patriarch of Family 
             Lord Montague          
             Lord Capulet      
               
        
        
            Matriarch of Family
             Lady Montague 
             Lady Capulet
            
        
        
            Servants to Family Heads   
            Abraham
             Sampson
            
        
        
            
            
             Gregory
            
        
        
            Only Child
             Romeo
             Juliet
            
        
        
            Servants to Children
             Balthasar
             Nurse
            
        
        
            
            
             Peter
            
        
        
             Hot-Head
             Mercutio
             Tybalt
            
        
        
             Peace-maker
             Benvolio
             Paris
            
        
        
             Royalty
            
            
             Prince Escalus
        
        
             Clergy
            
            
             Friar Lawrence Friar John
        
    

As you read, keep this chart handy in order to understand family allegiance and roles.


Assignment: Read Act I of Romeo & Juliet by William Shakespeare (original and modern text side by side)

Watch the following videos to learn more: 
Of Pentameter & Bear Baiting - Romeo & Juliet Part I



Love or Lust? Romeo and Juliet Part II

mainContent.html:
5.1 Who's Who in Verona: Romeo and Juliet

Completion requirements

If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 5, you can open it in Google Docs. Use the study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too. Review the assignment for this unit. Think about it as you are reading the book. Collect ideas and make notes. 

The Play's the Thing

Shakespeare's Tragedy of Romeo & Juliet is an early play by the great Elizabethan playwright, adapted from an Italian story of romance.  In the play, Shakespeare confronts the dualities of love and death, those two extremes that propel the young lovers into each others' arms.  

The play begins with a sonnet which, *SPOILER*, gives a synopsis of the play by the Chorus as a kind of preview that you might see in a movie theater.  His famous line about the "star-crossed lovers" juxtaposes the fate versus free will themes of love and death.  It's a classic teenage romance in which we are ironically attracted to those who may both love and hurt us most.

The play's setting, the city-state of Verona, Italy, tells of two rival families, the Montagues (Romeo's family) and Capulets (Juliet's family).  Each family mirrors the other according to character parallels or foils (reflections of each other):
Who's Who in Verona Montagues Capulets Neutral
Patriarch of Family   Lord Montague            Lord Capulet          
Matriarch of Family  Lady Montague   Lady Capulet
Servants to Family Heads    Abraham  Sampson
 Gregory
Only Child  Romeo  Juliet
Servants to Children  Balthasar  Nurse
 Peter
 Hot-Head  Mercutio  Tybalt
 Peace-maker  Benvolio  Paris
 Royalty  Prince Escalus
 Clergy  Friar Lawrence
 Friar John

As you read, keep this chart handy in order to understand family allegiance and roles.

Assignment: Read Act I of Romeo & Juliet by William Shakespeare (original and modern text side by side)

Watch the following videos to learn more: 

Of Pentameter & Bear Baiting - Romeo & Juliet Part I

Love or Lust? Romeo and Juliet Part II


Reading:

An Introduction to the play
